prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal is for detecting [NII]122 in BR 1202-0725 at z~4.7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary purpose of this Science Goal is detecting the [NII]122 emission (rest-frame wavelength and frequency: 121.898 micron and 2459.380 GHz) in a high-z galaxy BR 1202-0725. This system consists of two components, BR1202N at z_opt = 4.6891 and BR1202S at z_opt = 4.6943 (e.g., Carniani et al. 2013, A\&A, 559, A29). Since the angular separation between these two system is ~3.6 arcsec, we can observe these two components simultaneously within one ALMA primary beam size. For these two components, the observed-frame wavelengths and frequencies are (693.490 micron, 432.295 GHz) and (694.124 micron, 431.900 GHz), respectively. The atmospheric transmission at these frequencies is relatively good in the Band 8. We will observe the [NII]122 emission lines from these two components by using 2 basebands (Baseband-1 and Baseband-2), that results in the frequency coverage from 430.37 GHz to 433.83 GHz (here we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz and apply a small overlap between the two basebands). Note that the expected [NII]122 velocity widths of BR1202N and BR1202S are 500 km/s and 300 km/s respectively (assuming that the [NII]122 and [CII]157 have similar velocity width; see Carniani et al. 2013); the current frequency coverage is safely cover these [NII] emission lines even by taking account of those velocity widths. The remaining 2 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wide-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 2 basebands. We set the frequency separation between Baseband-3 and Baseband-4 to be 1.6 GHz, for covering the continuum emission continuously without a gap between 2 basebands. For reducing the data rate of this science goal, we adopt 8 channel binning in Baseband-1 and Baseband-2 (for [NII]122) and 16 channel binning for the remaining 2 basebands (for continuum). This results in the data rate of 2.0 MB/sec, that is below the "expected average data rate" (6 MB/sec). Note that this velocity binning does not affect our scientific analysis at all, because the resulting velocity resolution in Baseband-1 and Baseband-2 (~2.7 km/s, after the 8 channel binning) is much finer than any velocity structures expected for sub-millimeter spectra of galaxies.
We have already measured the [CII]157 emission-line flux for this system, and the measured peak flux densities for the [CII]157 emission are 13 mJy for BR1202N and 18 mJy for BR1202S (see Fig. 3 in Carniani et al. 2013). Assuming a typical flux ratio of [NII]122/[CII]157 = 0.14 (that is an average for low-z galaxies; Farrah et al. 2013, ApJ, 776, 38) and the same velocity width between [NII]122 and [CII]157, we expect that the peak flux densities of [NII]122 are 1.82 mJy and 2.52 mJy for BR1202N and BR1202S respectively. In order to detect this [NII]122 emission with S/N = 5, the required sensitivity is 0.364 mJy (rms). By adopting 150 km/s velocity width for the time estimate (given the velocity widths of 500 km/s and 300 km/s for BR1202N and BR1202S), the required observing time is 1.79 hours (on-source), that corresponds to 4.02 hours including calibrations and overheads.
For this Science Goal, we do not need to resolve the internal structure for each component. Thus the required angular resolution is specified to be 1.0 arcsec. Note that the angular separation between the two components is ~3.6 arcsec, we can clearly separate these two components spatially in the obtained ALMA data. Therefore we do not use the ACA. No scheduling time constraints for this Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [OI]145
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal is for detecting [OI]145 in BR1202-0725 at z~4.7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary purpose of this Science Goal is detecting the [OI]145 emission (rest-frame wavelength and frequency: 145.525 micron and 2060.069 GHz) in a high-z galaxy BR 1202-0725. This system consists of two components, BR1202N at z_opt = 4.6891 and BR1202S at z_opt = 4.6943 (e.g., Carniani et al. 2013, A\&A, 559, A29). Since the angular separation between these two system is ~3.6 arcsec, we can observe these two components simultaneously within one ALMA primary beam size. For these two components, the observed-frame wavelengths and frequencies are (827.906 micron, 362.109 GHz) and (828.663 micron, 361.779 GHz), respectively. The atmospheric transmission at these frequencies is relatively good in the Band 7. We will observe the [OI]145 emission lines from these two components by using 2 basebands (Baseband-1 and Baseband-2), that results in the frequency coverage from 360.22 GHz to 363.68 GHz (here we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz). Note that the expected [OI]145 velocity widths of BR1202N and BR1202S are 500 km/s and 300 km/s respectively (assuming that the [OI]145 and [CII]157 have similar velocity width; see Carniani et al. 2013); the current frequency coverage is safely cover these [OI]145 emission lines even by taking account of those velocity widths. The remaining 2 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wide-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 2 basebands. We set the frequency separation between Baseband-3 and Baseband-4 to be 1.6 GHz, for covering the continuum emission continuously without a gap between 2 basebands. For reducing the data rate of this science goal, we adopt 8 channel binning in Baseband-1 and Baseband-2 (for [OI]145) and 16 channel binning for the remaining 2 basebands (continuum). This results in the data rate of 2.0 MB/sec, that is below the "expected average data rate" (6 MB/sec). Note that this velocity binning does not affect our scientific analysis at all, because the resulting velocity resolution in Baseband-1 and Baseband-2 (~3.2 km/s, after the 8 channel binning) is much finer than any velocity structures expected for sub-millimeter spectra of galaxies.
We have already measured the [CII]157 emission-line flux for this system, and the measured peak flux densities for the [CII]157 emission are 13 mJy for BR1202N and 18 mJy for BR1202S (see Fig. 3 in Carniani et al. 2013). Assuming a typical flux ratio of [OI]145/[CII]157 = 0.13 (that is an average for low-z galaxies; Farrah et al. 2013, ApJ, 776, 38) and the same velocity width between [OI]145 and [CII]157, we expect that the peak flux densities of [OI]145 are 1.69 mJy and 2.34 mJy for BR1202N and BR1202S respectively. In order to detect this [OI]145 emission with S/N = 5, the required sensitivity is 0.338 mJy (rms). By adopting 150 km/s velocity width for the time estimate (given the velocity widths of 500 km/s and 300 km/s for BR1202N and BR1202S), the required observing time is 23.47 minutes (on-source), that corresponds to 1.03 hours including calibrations and overheads.
For this Science Goal, we do not need to resolve the internal structure for each component. Thus the required angular resolution is specified to be 1.0 arcsec. Note that the angular separation between the two components is ~3.6 arcsec, we can clearly separate these two components spatially in the obtained ALMA data. Therefore we do not use the ACA. No scheduling time constraints for this Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [NII]205
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal is for detecting [NII]205 in BR1202-0725 at z~4.7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary purpose of this Science Goal is detecting the [NII]205 emission (rest-frame wavelength and frequency: 205.178 micron and 1461.131 GHz) in a high-z galaxy BR 1202-0725. This system consists of two components, BR1202N at z_opt = 4.6891 and BR1202S at z_opt = 4.6943 (e.g., Carniani et al. 2013, A\&A, 559, A29). Since the angular separation between these two objects is ~3.6 arcsec, we can observe these two components simultaneously. For these two components, the observed-frame wavelengths and frequencies are (1167.278 micron, 256.830 GHz) and (1168.345 micron, 256.596 GHz), respectively. The atmospheric transmission at these frequencies is relatively good in the Band 6. We will observe the [NII]205 emission lines from these two components by using 2 basebands (Baseband-1 and Baseband-2), that results in the frequency coverage from 254.98 GHz to 258.44 GHz (here we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz). Note that the expected [NII]205 velocity widths of BR1202N and BR1202S are 500 km/s and 300 km/s respectively (assuming that the [NII]205 and [CII]157 have similar velocity width; see Carniani et al. 2013); the current frequency coverage is safely cover these [NII] emission lines even by taking account of those velocity widths. One of the remaining 2 basebands (Baseband-3) is used to cover the CO(12-11) emission line. Note that the detection of this CO(12-11) emission line is not mandatory in this project (but could be useful if we will detect this emission line by chance), and thus we do not care this emission line for the sensitivity calculation. The remaining 1 baseband (Baseband-4) is used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wide-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for this Baseband-4. We set the frequency separation between Baseband-3 and Baseband-4 to be 1.6 GHz, for covering the continuum emission continuously without a gap between 2 basebands. For reducing the data rate of this science goal, we adopt 8 channel binning for Baseband-1, Baseband-2, and Baseband-3, while 16 channel binning for Baseband-4. This results in the data rate of 2.4 MB/sec, that is below the "expected average data rate" (6 MB/sec). Note that this velocity binning does not affect our scientific analysis at all, because the resulting velocity resolution in Baseband-1 and Baseband-2 (~4.6 km/s, after the 8 channel binning) is much finer than any velocity structures expected for sub-millimeter spectra of galaxies.
We have already measured the [CII]157 emission-line flux for this system, and the measured peak flux densities for the [CII]157 emission are 13 mJy for BR1202N and 18 mJy for BR1202S (see Fig. 3 in Carniani et al. 2013). Assuming a conservative flux ratio of [NII]205/[CII]157 = 0.05 (that is expected for galaxies with sub-solar metallicity but our targets could have a higher metallicity and thus a higher [NII]205/[CII]157 ratio; see Nagao et al. 2012, A\&A, 542, L34) and the same velocity width between [NI]205 and [CII]157, we expect that the peak flux densities of [NII]205 are 0.65 mJy and 0.90 mJy for BR1202N and BR1202S respectively. In order to detect this [NII]205 emission with S/N = 5, the required sensitivity is 0.13 mJy (rms). By adopting 150 km/s velocity width for the time estimate (given the velocity widths of 500 km/s and 300 km/s for BR1202N and BR1202S), the required observing time is 55.34 minutes (on-source), that corresponds to 2.03 hours including calibrations and overheads.
For this Science Goal, we do not need to resolve the internal structure for each component. Thus the required angular resolution is specified to be 1.0 arcsec. Note that the angular separation between the two components is ~3.6 arcsec, we can clearly separate these two components spatially in the obtained ALMA data. Therefore we do not use the ACA. No scheduling time constraints for this Science Goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The physical and chemical properties of the interstellar matter (ISM) and their redshift evolution are crucially important to understand the evolution of galaxies. Rest-frame optical diagnostics are not useful at z>3.5 due to the limited NIR atmospheric transmission window, that prevents us from investigating the quantitative assessment of the ISM in high-z galaxies. However, the superb sensitivity of ALMA enables us to observe some fine-structure lines at high redshifts, that can be used to study the nature of the ISM. Here we focus on a strong [CII] emitter, BR 1202-0725 at z=4.69. Thanks to its high [CII] luminosity and optimal redshift, we can observe [NII]122, [OI]145, and [NII]205 (in Band 8, 7, and 6) within a realistic observing time. By comparing the obtained emission-line flux ratios with our theoretical models, we will investigate the gas density, metallicity, and possible truncation of the PDR, in this system. Since this system consists of a SMG and a QSO, we can also study the possible AGN effects on the ISM properties. This project will bring us brand-new clues to understand the baryonic evolution of galaxies and the IGM cosmic reionization.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
